{{for|the blues-rock trio|Soledad Brothers (band)}} The '''Soledad Brothers''' were three [[African-American]] inmates charged with the murder of a white prison guard, John Vincent Mills, at California's [[Correctional Training Facility|Soledad Prison]] on January 16, 1970.{{Cite news|title=Prison Guard Is Beaten to Death|newspaper=[[Beaver County Times]]|date=January 17, 1970|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8bAiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=M7MFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3630,3871188&dq|accessdate=August 14, 2010}} [[George Jackson (Black Panther)|George Jackson]], Fleeta Drumgo, and John Clutchette were said to have murdered Mills in retaliation for the shooting deaths of three black prisoners during a prison fight in the exercise yard three days prior by another guard, Opie G. Miller. ==Soledad Prison== [[George Jackson (Black Panther)|George Jackson]] met W.L. Nolen through the [[Black Panther Party]] in Soledad State Prison in 1969. They were transferred together to the O Wing, along with Drumgo and Clutchette, which was considered the worst part of the adjustment center of which Max Row is a part. According to Jackson, in the O Wing "the strongest hold out no more than a couple of weeks. It destroys the logical processes of the mind, a man's thoughts become completely disorganized. The noise, madness streaming from every throat, frustrated sounds from the bars, metallic sounds from the walls, the steel trays, the iron beds bolted to the wall, the hollow sounds from a cast-iron sink or toilet. The smells, the human waste thrown at us, unwashed bodies, the rotten food. When a white con leaves here he's ruined for life. No black leaves Max Row walking. Either he leaves on the meat wagon or he leaves crawling licking at the pig's feet."{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=George|authorlink=George Jackson (Black Panther)|title=Soledad Brother: The Prison Letters of George Jackson|publisher = Longmans Canada Limited|year=1970|location=Toronto, Canada|isbn=978-0698103474}} In Jackson's letters from the prison he describes the attitude of the staff toward the convicts as both defensive and hostile, apparently out of pure malevolence. His account of life at the prison was used by the Soledad Brothers Defense Committee.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} ==Prison yard riot== On January 13, 1970, 14 black inmates and 2 white inmates from the [[prison#Security levels|maximum-security]] section of Soledad Prison were released into a recreation yard. It had been several months since they were last released into the yard.{{cite news|title=Last vestiges of radical movement will go on trial in Bingham case|first=Lary|last=Hatfield|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RDlSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RzYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4907%2C1089678|newspaper=The Day|publisher=The Day Publishing Company|location=New London, Connecticut|date=January 7, 1985|pages=1–4|accessdate=July 15, 2011}}{{cite book|last=Aptheker|first=Bettina|title=The Morning Breaks: The Trial of Angela Davis|publisher=Cornell University Press|year=1969|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yA9vwr6g8cMC|isbn=0-8014-8597-5}} The black prisoners were ordered to the far end of the yard, while the white prisoners remained near the center of the yard. Officer Opie G. Miller, an expert [[marksman]] armed with a rifle, watched over the inmates from a [[guard tower]] {{convert|13|ft|m|0}} above the yard. A [[fist fight]] ensued and Miller opened fire on the prisoners below. No [[warning shot]] was fired. Three black inmates were killed in the shooting: W.L. Nolen and Cleveland Edwards died in the yard, while Alvin Miller died in the prison hospital a few hours later. A white inmate, Billy D. Harris, was wounded in the groin by Miller's fourth shot, and ended up losing a testicle. In a letter from June 10, 1970, George Jackson described the scene as seeing three of his brothers having been "murdered [...] by a pig shooting from 30 feet above their heads with a military rifle." Following the incident, thirteen black prisoners began a hunger strike in the hopes of securing an investigation.{{Cite news|title=Negro Prisoners Begin Hunger Strike in Bid for Investigation|newspaper=[[The Bulletin (Bend)|The Bulletin]]|date=January 15, 1970|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zKQSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HPcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1453,3541718&dq=miller+guard&hl=en|accessdate=August 11, 2010}} On January 16, 1970, a [[Monterey County]] [[grand jury]] convened, then exonerated Miller in the deaths of Nolen, Edwards, and Miller with a ruling of "[[justifiable homicide]]". No black inmates were permitted to testify, including those who had been in the recreation yard during the shooting. In Soledad Prison, inmates heard the grand jury's ruling on the prison radio. Thirty minutes later, John V. Mills was found dying in another maximum-security wing of the prison, having been beaten and thrown from a third-floor tier of Y Wing, George Jackson's cellblock, to the television room below. On February 14, 1970, after an investigation into Mills' death by prison officials, George Lester Jackson, Fleeta Drumgo and John Wesley Clutchette were indicted by the Monterey County grand jury for [[first-degree murder]]. ==Soledad Brothers Defense Committee== The Soledad Brothers Defense Committee was formed by [[Fay Stender]] to assist in publicizing the case and raising funds to defend Jackson, Drumgo, and Clutchette. Among the several celebrities, writers, and left-wing political activists that supported the SBDC and their cause were [[Julian Bond]], [[Kay Boyle]], [[Marlon Brando]], [[Jane Fonda]], [[Noam Chomsky]], [[Lawrence Ferlinghetti]], [[Allen Ginsberg]], [[Tom Hayden]], [[William Kunstler]], [[Jessica Mitford]], [[Linus Pauling]], [[Pete Seeger]], [[Benjamin Spock]], and [[Angela Davis]].{{cite book |last1=Andrews|first1=Lori|authorlink1=Lori Andrews|title=Black Power, White Blood: The Life and Times of Johnny Spain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UKmKSuzduK8C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=1999|origyear=1996|publisher=Temple University Press|location=Philadelphia|isbn=9781566397506|page=130}}{{cite book|last1=Bernstein|first1=Lee|title=America is the Prison: Arts and Politics in Prison in the 1970s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a3yRlKxxDtkC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=July 12, 2011|year=2010|publisher=University of North Carolina Press|location=Chapel Hill, North Carolina|isbn=9780807871171|chapter=The Age of Jackson: George Jackson and the Radical Critique of Incarceration |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=a3yRlKxxDtkC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA51#v=onepage&q&f=false}}{{cite news|title=New Rebellion Brewing Inside Nation's Prisons|first=Austin|last=Scott|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oCgeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NbkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7115%2C3538937|agency=AP|newspaper=The Tuscaloosa News|location=Tuscaloosa, Alabama|date=October 18, 1970|accessdate=July 13, 2011}} In June 1970, California State Senator [[Mervyn Dymally]] and the [[California Legislative Black Caucus]] pursued an investigation of Soledad Prison and released a report that tried to legitimize the Committee and give it some credibility. Public reaction was mixed.{{cite book|title=The Morning Breaks: The Trial of Angela Davis|author=Aptheker, B.|date=1999|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=9780801485978|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yA9vwr6g8cMC|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} By the middle of that month, Davis was leading the movement. Stender also arranged the publication of ''Soledad Brother: The Prison Letters of George Jackson'', which was to contain various letters written by Jackson while in prison detailing his time spent in the prison throughout the trial. ==Jonathan Jackson's attempt to free the Soledad Brothers== {{Main|Marin County courthouse incident}} On August 7, 1970, George Jackson's seventeen-year-old brother [[Jonathan P. Jackson|Jonathan]] held up a courtroom during the trial of prisoner [[James McClain]], charged at the time with the attempted stabbing of a Soledad guard at the [[Marin County Civic Center]]. Jonathan Jackson, after having armed McClain, temporarily freed three San Quentin prisoners, and took Superior Court Judge [[Harold Haley]], Deputy District Attorney Gary Thomas, and three women on the jury hostage to secure the freedom of the "Soledad Brothers". Jackson, McClain, Haley, and a prisoner named William Christmas were killed as they attempted to drive away from the courthouse. Haley died due to the discharge of a [[sawed-off shotgun]] that had been fastened to his neck with adhesive tape by the abductors. Thomas, prisoner [[Ruchell Magee]], and one of the jurors were wounded.{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,909547-1,00.html|title=Justice: A Bad Week for the Good Guys|accessdate=June 4, 2008|date=August 1970|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]''}} Two days after his brother's death, in George Jackson's last letter in his collection of letters written while in prison, he wrote a letter to his deceased brother, signing it:
Cold and calm though.
'All right, gentlemen, I'm taking over now.' {{#tag:ref|The final words Jonathan Jackson used in the San Rafael courthouse.|group="nb"}}
Revolution, George"
[[Angela Davis]], who purchased the guns used in the escape attempt, was later tried on several charges in connection with the escape. A jury found her not guilty on murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy charges.Caldwell. Earl. "Angela Davis Acquitted on All Charges", ''The New York Times'', June 5, 1972. ==San Quentin Six== {{Main|San Quentin Six}} On August 21, 1971, days before his trial in the guard's killing, the 29-year-old Jackson allegedly launched a riot at San Quentin with a 9 mm [[pistol]]. There is controversy over the course of events that led to Jackson's obtaining of the firearm. Prison officials alleged that Stephen Bingham, the attorney who replaced Fay Stender{{#tag:ref|Eight years after George Jackson's death, Fay Stender was shot in 1979, allegedly by a member of the Black Guerilla Family for not supporting Jackson's militarist politics. She suffered severe injuries that led to her paralysis. Stender committed suicide in May, 1980.James, Joy. ''Imprisoned Intellectuals: America's Political Prisoners Write on Life, Liberation, and Rebellion''. New York, New York: Rowman and Littlefield Publishers, Inc. pp. 86-87; {{ISBN|978-0742520271}}.|group="nb"}} as Jackson's attorney, visited Jackson. Bingham was alleged to have smuggled Jackson a pistol and an Afro wig. He was purported to have given a wig to Jackson within in which to hide the gun. However, Bingham was found not guilty of this charge in an ensuing trial in 1986. Prison officials had claimed that as Jackson was attempting to leave his meeting with Bingham, a gun protruded from a wig he was wearing and Jackson was asked to show the object. With a gun in hand, Jackson released an entire floor of prisoners from the maximum-security wing, allegedly saying, "This is it, gentlemen, the Dragon has come!" In the ensuing melee, three guards were killed, as were two prisoners suspected of being snitches, before George Jackson rushed out into the yard where he was shot and killed by a guard. Other people involved in the case believe Jackson's death was a setup by prison authorities, who conspired to supply Jackson with a gun, in the hopes that he would be killed in the ensuing melee, allegedly because they saw his power as a threat to their control and authority. Inconsistencies in the stories, although common among eyewitnesses in many crimes, fueled the controversy and helped to set off an uprising at [[Attica Correctional Facility]] in New York three weeks later. Bingham's acquittal in 1986 on charges that he smuggled Jackson a gun and a wig, and was thereby responsible for the escape attempt and murders, occurred after he emerged from hiding for 13 years in order to stand trial.{{cite news |title=People In The News: Ex-fugitive finally feels free, retains his political activism |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=auhVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eOEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6900%2C6635723 |newspaper=The Register-Guard |location=Eugene, Oregon |date=June 28, 1987 |page=2A |accessdate=July 13, 2012}} ==Trial== In [[San Francisco]], proceedings were held in the Department 21 courtroom on the third floor of the [[Hall of Justice#San Francisco|Hall of Justice]], the same courtroom in which [[Ruchell Magee]] would later be tried on charges related to the murder of Judge Haley.{{cite news|title='Soledad Brothers' Conflict Incites 11 Violent Deaths|first=Harold V.|last=Streeter|url=http://jfk.hood.edu/Collection/White%20%20Files/San%20Quentin/San%20Quentin%20097.pdf||newspaper=San Francisco Examiner|location=San Francisco, California|date=August 29, 1971|accessdate=July 21, 2010}}{{cite news|title=Magee Trial – Dullsville Revisited|first=Harold V.|last=Streeter|url=http://jfk.hood.edu/Collection/White%20%20Files/San%20Quentin/San%20Quentin%20748.pdf|format=pdf|location=San Francisco, California|date=August 18, 1972|accessdate=July 21, 2010}} Spectators, including the press, were separated from the proceedings by a $15,000 floor-to-ceiling barrier constructed of metal, wood, and bullet-proof glass.{{#tag:ref|The barrier was also reported to be soundproof, thereby requiring a public address system so that spectators could hear the proceedings.|group="nb"}} Throughout the trial, there were attempts to annul the proceedings on technicalities. There were complaints on behalf of the defendants that they were not informed of the scheduled court hearing, specifically in a letter from George Jackson on June 13, 1970. They also claimed the court report stated that 1-48 pages of the testimony were recorded and they were only given 1-46 pages of testimony. After Jackson's death, on March 27, 1972, the two surviving Soledad Brothers—Clutchette and Drumgo—were acquitted by a San Francisco jury of the original charges of murdering a prison guard on the grounds that the state had failed to completely prove its case."Acquit Soledad Brothers", ''Pacific Stars and Stripes'', March 29, 1972, p. 1 ==Notes== ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * ''Soledad Brother: The Prison Letters of George Jackson'' (1970). {{ISBN|1-55652-230-4}} * Min S Yee. ''The Melancholy History of Soledad Prison; In Which a Utopian Scheme Turns Bedlam'' (1973). {{ISBN|0-06-129800-X}} [[Category:History of the United States (1964–80)]] [[Category:Quantified groups of defendants]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of California]] [[Category:Trials in the United States]] [[Category:20th century American trials]]

{{ref improve|date=December 2013}} {{Politics of Bulgaria}} The '''Supreme Administrative Court''' of [[Bulgaria]] was first established on 25 November 1878 as one of the three divisions of the then-single [[Supreme court|Supreme Court]]. It did not exist during the [[History of the People's Republic of Bulgaria|Communist rule]], but was restored in 1991. The purpose of the Court is outlined in the [[Constitution of Bulgaria|Constitution]]: '' "Article 125 (1) The Supreme Administrative Court shall exercise supreme judicial oversight as to the precise and equal application of the law in administrative justice. (2) The Supreme Administrative Court shall rule on all challenges to the legality of acts of the [[Council of Ministers of Bulgaria|Council of Ministers]] and the individual ministers, and of other acts established by law. '' The Supreme Administrative Court became a separate institution with the promulgation of the Administrative Justice Law from 3 April 1912. The Constitution of the People’s Republic of Bulgaria of 1947 did not provide for judicial supervision over administrative acts, and as a result the Supreme Administrative Court was closed in 1948 by virtue of the Law on the Structure of People’s Courts. Bulgaria's seventh Grand National Assembly reestablished the Court in 1991. The current Chairman of the Supreme Administrative Court is Georgi Kolev. He was appointed to this position in 2010. The Deputies are Veneta Markovska and Galina Solakova. The Court consists of two colleges and six divisions, each with a particular phere of responsibilities. The Supreme Administrative Court publishes a periodical, the Administrative Justice Journal. It is used to describe the problems of Administrative Law and to present practices from the relevant European judicial institutions. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.sac.government.bg/|Court's official website}}

'''Texas Tax Code Chapter 313''' (aka the ''Texas Economic Development Act'') creates a state program for certain large businesses to limit the appraised value on their property for the purposes of local Texas public school district property taxes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://statutes.capitol.texas.gov/Docs/TX/htm/TX.313.htm|title=Tax Code Chapter 313 Texas Economic Development Act|last=|first=|date=|website=statutes.capitol.texas.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref>
An appraised value limitation is an agreement between a taxpayer and a Texas school district in which the taxpayer proposes to build or install property--and create jobs meeting certain job and wage requirements--in exchange for a ten-year limitation on the taxpayer's property value for school district maintenance and operations tax (M&O) purposes. For ten years, school M&O property taxes are not levied on the value in excess of the limitation amount. Limitation amounts are established by statute and vary by school district from $10 million to $100 million.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/fiscal-notes/2016/april/chap313.php|title=Chapter 313: Attracting Jobs and Investment|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=April 2016|website=comptroller.texas.gov|series=Fiscal Notes|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304003917/https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/fiscal-notes/2016/april/chap313.php|archive-date=March 4, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref> Unlike abatements based on a percentage of the property value, the structure of the program benefits primarily extremely large projects. The majority of projects are in the petrochemical or energy sectors, although some are typical manufacturing.
Created by the Texas legislature in 2001, and initially set to expire in 2007, the program has been renewed several times. In 2013, the Texas Legislature reset the expiration date of the program to December 31, 2022.<ref name=":3">Texas Legislature, 83rd Regular Session, [https://capitol.texas.gov/BillLookup/History.aspx?LegSess=83R&Bill=HB3390 House Bill 3390] </ref>
Companies seeking a limitation submit an abatement application to the school district in which the project may be located. The school district forwards the application to the Texas Comptroller for evaluation. The school district may not grant final approval of the abatement without Comptroller analysis and approval.<ref name=":0" /> For the 10 years of the tax benefit period, reduced local school district revenues are substantially replaced with state funds through the state public school finance system.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/docs/96-1359-2016.pdf|title=A Report of the Texas Economic Development Act, 2017|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=January 2017|website=|page=a|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170304104052/https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/docs/96-1359-2016.pdf|archive-date=September 6, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The Texas Tax Code gives to the Texas Comptroller's office responsibility and authority to adopt rules necessary for the implementation and administration or the program.<ref>Texas Tax Code [https://statutes.capitol.texas.gov/Docs/TX/htm/TX.313.htm#313.031 §313.031(1)]</ref> The Comptroller's office delegates to school districts the responsibility to enforce provisions of the limitation agreements.<ref>Texas Administrative Code, Title 34, Part 1, Chapter 9, Subchapter F, [http://texreg.sos.state.tx.us/public/readtac$ext.TacPage?sl=R&app=9&p_dir=&p_rloc=&p_tloc=&p_ploc=&pg=1&p_tac=&ti=34&pt=1&ch=9&rl=1054 Rule §9.1054(i)(3)]</ref> In 2013, in House Bill 3390, the Texas legislature charged the Comptroller's office with reviewing the number of qualifying jobs created in future projects receiving tax limitations.<ref name=":3" />
The Texas Comptroller's website posts documents related to the projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/local/ch313/agreement-docs.php?_ga=1.213457943.2073348964.1474830232|title=Chapter 313 School Value Limitation Documents|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Program Costs == A 2017 report to the Texas Legislature by the Texas Comptroller reported 311 active limitation agreements, representing an estimated $146 billion of total investment through 2033.<ref name=":1" /> That report indicated that between 2002 and 2015, local school property tax revenue reductions due to limitation agreements were approximately $7.1 billion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/docs/96-1359-2016.pdf|title=A Report of the Texas Economic Development Act, 2017|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=January 2017|website=|page=3|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170304104052/https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/docs/96-1359-2016.pdf|archive-date=September 6, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
A "''Tax Exemptions and Tax Incidence Report''" prepared by the Texas Comptroller in February, 2017, estimated that limitation agreements would reduce school districts revenues in that year by about $513 million, also indicating that total school district revenue could be reduced by over $1 billion annually by the year 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chron.com/business/texanomics/article/Texas-biggest-economic-development-incentive-10916880.php|title=Texas' Biggest Tax Incentive Set to Double by 2022|last=DePillis|first=Lydia|date=February 8, 2017|website=|publisher=Houston Chronicle|url-access=limited|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215223431/https://www.chron.com/business/texanomics/article/Texas-biggest-economic-development-incentive-10916880.php|archive-date=February 15, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/transparency/reports/tax-exemptions-and-incidence/2017/96-463.pdf|title=Tax Exemptions and Tax Incidence Reports|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=February 2017|website=|page=36|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasobserver.org/texas-largest-corporate-welfare-program-rapidly-ballooning/|title=Texas' Largest Corporate Welfare Program is Rapidly Ballooning|last=Sadasivam|first=Naveena|date=February 13, 2017|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213193459/https://www.texasobserver.org/texas-largest-corporate-welfare-program-rapidly-ballooning/|archive-date=February 13, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Program Supporters == Supporters of the program argue that Texas' high local property tax rates put the state at a disadvantage when competing for businesses making new investments. Business groups say the program attracts projects that would have not come to Texas otherwise, and that without the program Texas cannot compete with other states for new business investment. Proponents of the program claim that local school district property revenue reductions created by the abatement do not create a real cost to the state, arguing that without the program, none of the businesses receiving the abatement would have located in Texas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ttara.org/files/document/file-4e36c23951e81.pdf|title=Questions and Answers about the Texas Economic Development Act|last=Texas Taxpayers and Research Association|first=|date=December 2010|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140719190541/http://www.ttara.org/files/document/file-4e36c23951e81.pdf|archive-date=July 18, 2014|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sachamber.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Texas2050-Sept-22-2016.pdf|title=Texas 2050 - A Framework for Long-Term Economic Growth|last=Texas 2050|first=|date=September 22, 2016|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531201431/https://www.sachamber.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Texas2050-Sept-22-2016.pdf|archive-date=May 31, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ttara.org/files/document/file-58862ea4ee69b.pdf|title=TTARA releases report on Chapter 313: State's 'single most important economic development tool'|last=Texas Taxpayers and Research Association|first=|date=January 23, 2017|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531141228/http://www.ttara.org/files/document/file-58862ea4ee69b.pdf|archive-date=May 31, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ttara.org/files/document/file-587e921ed3196.pdf|title=Understanding Chapter 313: School Property Tax Limitations and the Impact on State Finances|last=Texas Taxpayers and Research Association|first=|date=January 2017|website=|page=7|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305225454/http://www.ttara.org/files/document/file-587e921ed3196.pdf|archive-date=March 5, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/opinion/outlook/article/Bennett-Craymer-Chapter-313-helps-keep-Texas-11056084.php|title=Chapter 313 helps keep Texas' status as an economic powerhouse|last=Craymer|first=Dale|last2=Bennett|first2=Tony|date=April 6, 2017|website=|publisher=Houston Chronicle - Guest Editorial|url-access=limited|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415003354/https://www.houstonchronicle.com/opinion/outlook/article/Bennett-Craymer-Chapter-313-helps-keep-Texas-11056084.php|archive-date=April 15, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Program Critics == Critics of the program argue that many of the projects receiving the abatement would have located in Texas for other reasons. Wind farms, they say, find Texas an ideal location due to its rich wind resources, separate electrical grid, and large rate-payer-funded transmission networks. They say that the program's petrochemical projects locate in Texas largely because of little regulation, proximity to rich oil and gas shale plays, and access to deep-water ports and pipeline networks. Critics also point to the relatively small number of jobs created compared to the large amount of revenues forgone for each job.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texaspolicy.com/content/detail/local-tax-incentives-chapter-313-texas-economic-development-act|title=Local Tax Incentives: Chapter 313 - Texas Economic Development A|last=Peacock|first=Bill|date=August 21, 2017|website=|publisher=Texas Public Policy Foundation|archive-url=https://www.scribd.com/document/356841557/CWG-Chapter-313-Texas-Economic-Development-Act#from_embed|archive-date=May 31, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasobserver.org/chapter-313-texas-tax-incentive/|title=Free Lunch|last=Michel|first=Patrick|date=March 14, 2016|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125102433/https://www.texasobserver.org/chapter-313-texas-tax-incentive/|archive-date=January 25, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mystatesman.com/news/big-dollars-little-oversight/KqNmdAArCJEG5Vm5qTGSbN/|title=Big dollars, little oversight? Amid debate over Texas' tax breaks for businesses, little attention being given to biggest incentives program of all|last=Toohey|first=Marty|date=May 17, 2015|website=|publisher=Austin American Statesman|url-access=limited|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531193851/https://www.mystatesman.com/news/big-dollars-little-oversight/KqNmdAArCJEG5Vm5qTGSbN/|archive-date=May 31, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=|subscription=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasobserver.org/point-isabel-isd-rio-grande-lng-tax-break/|title=Once Again, School District Shuts Down Tax Break for Gas Exporter|last=Michels|first=Patrick|date=September 22, 2016|website=|publisher=Texas Observer|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130145507/https://www.texasobserver.org/point-isabel-isd-rio-grande-lng-tax-break/|archive-date=November 30, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasobserver.org/rationale-for-texas-largest-corporate-welfare-program-was-a-typographical-error/|title=Rationale for Texas' Largest Corporate Welfare Program was a 'Typographical Error'|last=Michels|first=Patrick|date=November 29, 2016|website=|publisher=Texas Observer|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130145507/https://www.texasobserver.org/rationale-for-texas-largest-corporate-welfare-program-was-a-typographical-error/|archive-date=November 30, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> They further claim program benefits are too generous, as many companies typically agree to return about 40 percent of the initial tax savings to the local school district through "payments in lieu of taxes" outside the regular system of school finance. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.journals.senate.texas.gov/SJRNL/83R/PDF/83RSJ05-26-F.PDF|title=Statement of Legislative Intent for HB 3390 (Senators Deuell, Davis and Watson)|last=Senate Journal - Texas Senate|first=|date=May 26, 2013|website=|publisher=Secretary of the Texas Senate|pages=3788–3796|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531200224/http://www.journals.senate.texas.gov/SJRNL/83R/PDF/83RSJ05-26-F.PDF|archive-date=May 31, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref name=":2" />
== Program Studies and Analyses == In 2010, the Comptrollers office studied the program, making recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/transparency/local/docs/96-1453.pdf|title=An Analysis of Texas Economic Development Incentives, 2010. Texas Economic Development Act: Chapter 313|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=March 2011|website=|pages=17–26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170304003259/https://comptroller.texas.gov/transparency/local/docs/96-1453.pdf|archive-date=March 3, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The Texas Legislative Budge Board in its ''Texas State Government Effectiveness and Efficiency: Selected Issues and Recommendations'' (January 2011) analyzed the Chapter 313 program, making recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lbb.state.tx.us/documents/publications/geer/geer01012011.pdf|title=Texas State Government Effectiveness and Efficiency; Selected Issues and Recommendations. "Improve the Administration of the Texas Economic Development Act"|last=Texas Legislative Budget Board|first=|date=January 2011|website=|page=|pages=1–10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180303221849/http://www.lbb.state.tx.us/documents/publications/geer/geer01012011.pdf|archive-date=March 3, 2013|dead-url=|access-date=|subscription=}}</ref> In 2013, the Chapter was amended to require the Texas State Auditor's Office (SAO) to review at least three major limitation agreements annually.<ref>Texas Tax Code §313.010</ref> The SAO has published reports for 2014,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sao.texas.gov/reports/main/15-009.pdf|title=Report No. 15-009 An Audit Report on Selected Major Agreements Under the Texas Economic Development Act|last=Texas State Auditor's Office|first=|date=November 2014|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223759/http://www.sao.texas.gov/reports/main/15-009.pdf|archive-date=December 22, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sao.texas.gov/reports/main/15-042.pdf|title=Report No. 15-042 An Audit of Selected Major Agreements Under the Texas Economic Development Act|last=Texas State Auditor's Office|first=|date=August 2015|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223414/http://www.sao.texas.gov/reports/main/15-042.pdf|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> 2016,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sao.texas.gov/reports/main/17-009.pdf|title=Report No. 17-009 An Audit Report on Selected Major Agreements Under the Texas Economic Development Act|last=Texas State Auditor's Office|first=|date=October 2016|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026190040/http://www.sao.texas.gov/reports/main/17-009.pdf|archive-date=October 26, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sao.texas.gov/Reports/Main/17-043.pdf|title=Report No. 17-043 An Audit on Selected Major Agreements Under the Texas Economic Development Act|last=Texas State Auditor's Office|first=|date=July 2017|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170903222205/https://www.sao.texas.gov/Reports/Main/17-043.pdf|archive-date=September 3, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In November, 2016, the Texas Senate Committee on Natural Resources and Economic Development issued an ''Interim Report to the 85th Legislature'' critical of the Chapter 313 program.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://senate.texas.gov/cmtes/85/c580/c580.InterimReport2016.pdf|title=Interim Report to the 85th Legislature|last=Senate Committee on Natural Resources and Economic Development|first=|date=November 2016|website=|pages=50–83|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531151539/https://senate.texas.gov/cmtes/85/c580/c580.InterimReport2016.pdf|archive-date=May 31, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts started issuing biennially reports on limitation economic development projects in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://comptroller.texas.gov/economy/local/ch313/biennial-reports.php|title=Biennial Reports|last=Texas Comptroller of Public Accounts|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2017, University of Texas political science professor Nathan M. Jensen released a study on the Chapter 313 program suggesting that most companies receiving the abatement would have located in Texas for other reasons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Depillis,|first=Lydia|date=|title=Study: Texas' biggest tax break program is mostly a waste of money|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/texanomics/article/Study-Texas-biggest-tax-break-program-is-mostly-10998045.php|journal=Houston Chronicle|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cdn.equitablegrowth.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/19153356/10242017-WP-exit-options-negotiations.pdf|title=Exit Options in Firm-Government Negotiations: An Evaluation of the Texas Chapter 313 Program|last=Jensen|first=Nathan M.|date=October 10, 2017|website=|publisher=Washington Center for Equitable Growth. revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name = The Hague Academy of International Law |native_name = Académie de droit international de La Haye |latin_name = |image = |motto = |established = 1923 |type = |endowment = |staff = |professors = |rector = |dean = |financial director = |head_label = |head = |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |location = [[Peace Palace]], [[The Hague]], Netherlands |state = |country = The Netherlands |coor = |campus = |colors = |affiliations = |website = [http://www.hagueacademy.nl/ hagueacademy.nl] }}[[File:International Court of Justice.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Peace Palace which houses the Hague Academy of International Law, pictured in March 2006]]
'''The Hague Academy of International Law''' ({{lang-fr|Académie de droit international de La Haye}}) is a center for high-level [[education]] in both [[public international law|public]] and [[conflict of laws|private international law]] housed in the [[Peace Palace]] in [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]]. Courses are taught in [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]] and, except for External Programme Courses, are held in the Peace Palace.
The Academy is famous for its Summer Courses Programme. [[List of Hague Academy of International Law people|The Academy's alumni]] and current/former faculty include heads of state, foreign ministers, ambassadors, 13 judges of the [[International Court of Justice]], one former [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]], [[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]] and two [[Nobel Prize]] recipients.
==History== [[File:TMCasser.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate [[Tobias Asser]] (1838–1913)]] Since its creation in 1923, The Hague Academy of International Law has occupied premises at the [[Peace Palace]]. Next to the Peace Palace building the Academy’s facilities include the Academy Hall built for international conferences, the Peace Palace Library as well as further administrative accommodations. The new buildings were planned and realized by architects [[Michael Wilford]] and Manuel Schupp. Alongside The Hague Academy of International Law the Peace Palace houses highest judicial institutions such as the [[International Court of Justice]] and the Bureau of the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]]. In the context of the movement for the establishment of peace through law, the idea of creating an Academy of International Law was mooted at the [[Hague Conference]] in 1907 (having previously been voiced by the [[Institut de Droit International]] as early as 1873). The Dutch Government took up the idea, and the [[International Law Association]] in turn examined the question. The Dutch Lawyer [[Tobias Asser|Tobias M. C. Asser]] proposed a plan that envisaged more or less what the Academy was to become, with courses held from July to October. Asser received the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 1911 and contributed a part of the prize money to the Academy; and the [[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|Carnegie Endowment for Peace]] provided a valuable contribution to get it started. The inauguration of the Academy was planned for October 1914. But [[World War I]] broke out, and preparations could not be resumed until 1921. When the Summer Courses started on 14 July 1923, at the Peace Palace in The Hague, 353 students originating from 31 countries attended, of whom 35 were women.
Today, the Academy is a centre for research and teaching in public and private international law, with the aim of further scientific and advanced studies of the legal aspects of international relations. The [[UN General Assembly]] regularly refers to the “valuable contribution” that the Academy “continues to make to the United Nations Program of Assistance in the Teaching, Study, Dissemination and Wider Appreciation of International Law”.<ref>[https://www.un.org/documents/ga/res/40/a40r066.htm see Resolution A/RES/40/66.]</ref> The Academy was awarded the [[Wateler Peace Prize]] (1936, 1950), the [[Félix Houphouët-Boigny Peace Prize]] (1992), the Order of Rio Branco,<ref>[[:pt:Ordem de Rio Branco|See Wikipedia page in Portuguese.]]</ref> Brazil (1999), and the Medal of the [[Royal Institute of European Studies]],<ref>[[:es:Real Instituto de Estudios Europeos|See Wikipedia page in spanish.]]</ref> Spain (2000). The Academy has been nominated for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] 34 times between 1915 and 1956.<ref>[http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/nomination/database.html See nobelprize.org.]</ref> The Academy is part of the [[Hague Academic Coalition]].
==The structure of the Academy==
===The Curatorium=== The Academy’s academic activities and policies are defined by the Curatorium. It consists of members of different nationalities, who are well known in the academic or diplomatic worlds, or practising international lawyers. The president of the Curatorium is a distinguished jurist who generally has extensive experience of international and diplomatic life. Among the most recent presidents have been [[Roberto Ago]], Nicolas Valticos and [[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]].
'''President'''
[[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]], Former [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]]. (died on 16-2-2016);
'''Vice-President'''
[[Erik Jayme]],<ref>[[:de:Erik Jayme|See Wikipedia page in german.]]</ref> Professor Emeritus at the Institute for Foreign and International Private and Commercial Law, Heidelberg;
'''Members'''
Geneviève Bastid-Burdeau, Professor at the [[Université Paris 1 Panthéon-Sorbonne|University Paris I (Panthéon-Sorbonne)]];
[[Antônio Augusto Cançado Trindade|Antônio Augusto Cançado-Trindade]], Judge at the [[International Court of Justice]] and former President of the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]];
[[James Crawford (jurist)|James Crawford]], [[Whewell Professor of International Law]], Cambridge;
Florentino P. Feliciano,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://legal.un.org/avl/faculty/Feliciano.html|title=AVL Faculty: Justice Florentino P. Feliciano|website=legal.un.org|access-date=2017-02-01}}</ref>{{cn|date=February 2016}} former Chairman, Appellate Body, [[WTO]]; former Senior Associate Justice, [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]];
Diego P. Fernandez Arroyo, Honorary Professor of the [[National University of Córdoba]], Professor at the [[Institut d'Études Politiques de Paris]];
Beat Hess, former group legal director, former member of the Executive Committee, [[Royal Dutch Shell]] plc;
Maarit Jänterä-Jareborg, Professor and former Dean at the Faculty of Law of [[Uppsala University]];
[[Djamchid Momtaz]], Professor at the [[University of Teheran]];
Shinya Murase, Professor at [[Sophia University]], Tokyo; Member of the [[United Nations International Law Commission]];
[[Raymond Ranjeva]], Former Vice-President of the [[International Court of Justice]];
[[Linos-Alexander Sicilianos]], Professor at the [[University of Athens]];
A. (Teun) V.M. Struycken, Professor emeritus at the [[Radboud University Nijmegen]]; Former President of the Netherlands Standing Government Committee on Private International Law;
[[Peter Tomka]], Judge and President of the [[International Court of Justice]];
Tullio Treves,<ref>[[:it:Tullio Treves|See Wikipedia page in italian.]]</ref> Professor at the [[University of Milan]], Judge to the [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]];
Peter D. Trooboff, Senior Counsel, [[Covington & Burling]], Washington, D.C.; Member of the District of Columbia and New York Bars;
[[Xue Hanqin|Hanqin Xue]], Judge at the [[International Court of Justice]];
'''Secretary General'''
Yves Daudet,<ref>[[:de:Yves Daudet|See Wikipedia page in german.]]</ref> Professor emeritus at the [[University of Paris 1|University Paris I (Panthéon-Sorbonne)]].
===The Administrative Council=== The Administrative Council is in charge of the financial and material aspects of the Academy’s operations. This is a Dutch body whose members are of Dutch nationality, and whose president is always a leading personality (at the moment, the former minister for foreign affairs, [[Ben Bot]]). The administrative Council has close ties with the [[Carnegie Foundation (Netherlands)|Dutch Carnegie Foundation]] which owns and manages the [[Peace Palace]].
==Programmes==
===Summer Courses=== The Summer Courses of the Academy are held in July (Public International Law<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?summer-programme/public-international-law Programme of the Public International Law session.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231031443/http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?summer-programme%2Fpublic-international-law |date=2010-12-31 }}</ref>) and August (Private International Law<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?summer-programme/private-international-law Programme of the Private International Law session.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029171717/http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?summer-programme%2Fprivate-international-law |date=2010-10-29 }}</ref>); each session lasts three weeks. The Academy is not a University: it does not have a permanent teaching staff, but its scientific body, the Curatorium, freely calls upon academics, practitioners, diplomats, and other personalities from all over the world whom it considers qualified to give courses, in English or French (with simultaneous interpretation). These courses are given in the form of a series of lectures, on general or special subjects. In principle, the courses are then published in the Collected Courses of the Academy of International Law, which now run to more than 360 volumes and are certainly among the most important encyclopædic publications on private and public international law.
The Summer programme is directed to advanced students and practitioners seeking a deeper understanding of international law, public or private. The summer courses are open to candidates who have completed at least four years of studying at university, including subjects of international law, and who can prove to the Curatorium that they possess a sufficient knowledge of the subject; to candidates holding a 3-year law degree at the opening of the session of the Academy. All candidates must master one of the two working languages (French or English). A merit-based scholarship program allows approximately 20% of the students to receive assistance from public and private funding sources.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?institutions-and-personalities List of donors, institutions and personalities.]</ref><ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?regulations Scholarships regulations.]</ref> Each year, attendees representing between 80 and 100 nationalities participate.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?summer-programme/represented-nationalities Represented nationalities.]</ref>
===Centre for Studies and Research in International Law and International Relations=== Since 1957,<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?centre-for-studies-and-research-in-international-law-and-international-relations/previous-sessions-of-the-centre Previous sessions of the Centre.]</ref> the Centre for Research is open, for three weeks from mid-August, to persons undertaking high-level research, working under the direction of professors who are highly qualified in the particular subject being studied, with the best results of the work being published in the Academy's collection. There are between 20 and 24 participants, half in the English-speaking section and half in the French-speaking section.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?centre-for-studies-and-research-in-international-law-and-international-relations/regulations-centre Centre regulations.]</ref>
Topics:
2010: International migrations
2011: Remedies for the actions of International Organizations
2012 : Criminal Acts at Sea
2013 : The Legal Implications of Global Financial Crises
===External Program=== At the end of the 1960s, the Academy established the Prestigious "External Program", which is normally held each year, in turn in Africa, Asia, and Latin America, upon the invitation of host governments or international organizations.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?external-programme/locations Locations where the sessions of the External Programme were successively held.]</ref>
The External Program is designed for around 20 participants from the countries in the region, whose travelling expenses are usually financed by the Academy and whose accommodation is financed by the government of the host State or organization. In addition, a number of participants come from the host state itself. [[GNLU]] in collaboration with the Hague Academy of International Law concluded the 2013 edition. <ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?external-programme/regulations-external External Programme regulations.]</ref>
==Academy diploma== The Hague Academy of International Law awards a high-level diploma for students who already have a thorough knowledge of international law and who pass an examination in either public international law or private international law.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?diploma-regulations Diploma regulations.]</ref> Few Diplomas are awarded each year, the examination being highly selective.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?awarded-diplomas Awarded Diplomas since 1950.]</ref>
==Doctoral scholarships== The Academy awards each year 4 doctoral scholarships. The beneficiaries stay for two months (July and August) in The Hague to pursue their doctoral researches. They can access the Peace Palace Library and attend the Summer Courses.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?doctoral-scholarships Conditions of admission to a doctoral scholarship on the Academy's website.]</ref> The candidates should come from a developing country and live there, their doctoral thesis should be in the process of completion.
==Publications== Since 1923, all courses given at the Academy are, in principle, published in the language in which they were delivered in the '''Collected Courses of the Hague Academy of International Law''' (in French : Recueil des cours de l'Académie de droit international de La Haye).<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?publications-en/collected-courses List of the published Collected Courses.]</ref> All the volumes of the Collected Courses which have been published since 1923 are available, since the very first volume (green binder), also in electronic format and paperback books<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?publications-en/pocket-books List of the published paperbooks.]</ref> for some courses. The series '''The Hague Academy of International Law Monographs''', proposes revised and updated versions of certain courses given during the Summer programme. The scientific works of the Centre, have been published, since the Centre’s 1985 session, in a publication in which the Directors of Studies report on the state of research of the Centre under their direction. When the work of the Centre has been of particular interest and originality, the reports of the Directors of Studies together with the articles by the researchers form the subject of a collection published in the series '''The Law Books of the Academy'''.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?publications-en/centre-for-studies-and-research List of the published works of the Centre].</ref> The Academy organizes Colloquia which works are published in the Law Books of the Academy series.
==The academy’s colloquia== Within the framework of a small working group, the Colloquia bring together specialists on the chosen subject from various countries of the world. The main objective of the colloquia, other than that of bringing together academics, diplomats and practitioners who have a common interest and knowledge of a specific theme, is to gather knowledge in that subject into a publication of high academic standard in the Legal Publications of the Academy series.<ref>[http://www.hagueacademy.nl/?publications-en/colloquium List of the colloqium published.]</ref> Very varied topics have been covered :
* 1968 – International Trade Agreements (1969)
* 1971 – Legal Aspects of Economic Integration (1972)
* 1973 – The Protection of the Environment and International Law (1975)
* 1978 – The Right to Health as a Human Right
* 1979 – The Right to Development at the International Level (1980)
* 1980 – The New International Economic Order. Commercial, Technological and Cultural Aspects (1981)
* 1981 – The Management of Humanity's Resources : The Law of the Sea (1982)
* 1982 – The Settlement of Disputes on the New Natural Resources (1983)
* 1983 – The Future of International Law in a Multicultural World (1984)
* 1984 – The Future of the International Law of the Environment (1985)
* 1985 – The Adaptation of Structures and Methods at the United Nations (1986)
* 1990 – The Peaceful Settlement of International Disputes in Europe: Future Prospects (1991)
* 1992 – The Development of the Role of the Security Council (1993)
* 1994 – The Convention on the Prohibition and Elimination of Chemicals Weapons:A Breakthrough in Multilateral Disarmament (1995)
* 2007 – Topicality of the 1907 Hague Conference, the second Peace Conference (2008)
==Bibliography== René-Jean Dupuy:<ref>[[:fr:René-Jean Dupuy|Biography in French on Wikipedia.]]</ref> Académie de droit international de La Haye: Livre jubilaire (1923–1973). A.W. Sijthoff, Leiden 1973
[[Robert Kolb]] : Les cours généraux de droit international public de l'Académie de La Haye. Bruylant, Bruxelles, 2003.
